summary_points: 1. At SBA Communications Corp.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 23, 2025, shareholders voted to elect three new Class II directors (Kevin L. Beebe, Jack Langer, and Jeffrey A. Stoops), ratify Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor, and approve (advisory) the named executive officers' compensation.
2.  The election of Kevin L. Beebe as a director received 90,780,910 votes "for," 6,960,797 votes "against," 43,713 abstentions, and 2,941,763 broker non-votes.
3.  The filing does not contain any information about future impacts or risks.
1. At Waters Corporation's May 22, 2025 annual meeting, approximately 94.12% of shares entitled to vote were present or represented by proxy.
2.  Christopher A. Kuebler received significantly fewer "For" votes (49,828,164) in the director election compared to other candidates, who received over 52 million votes.
3. Stockholders approved the Amended and Restated 2009 Employee Stock Purchase Plan at the May 22, 2025 meeting.

1. On May 23, 2025, PepsiCo terminated two revolving credit agreements (a $5 billion 364-day agreement and a $5 billion five-year agreement) and immediately replaced them with new agreements of the same amount.
2. The new five-year agreement, expiring May 23, 2030, includes a $750 million swing line subfacility for Euro-denominated borrowings.
3. PepsiCo can request a two-time extension of the new five-year credit agreement for an additional year each time.
1. LyondellBasell Industries N.V. shareholders approved a new share repurchase program on May 23, 2025, authorizing the repurchase of up to 34,042,250 shares until November 23, 2026.
2.  At the annual general meeting, approximately 91.57% of shares entitled to vote were represented, with all proposals receiving shareholder approval.

3. The  share repurchase program's execution is contingent on market and economic conditions, as well as legal requirements and other corporate considerations;  the company is not obligated to buy any specific number of shares.
1. DaVita Inc. completed a private offering of $1 billion in 6.750% Senior Notes due 2033 on May 23, 2025, receiving net proceeds of approximately $986 million.

2.  The net proceeds will primarily be used to repay $830 million in outstanding revolving credit facility borrowings, with the remaining funds allocated to general corporate purposes, potentially including stock repurchases.
3. The 2033 Notes are unsecured senior obligations, ranking equally with other existing and future senior indebtedness but subordinated to secured debt and liabilities of non-guarantor subsidiaries.
1. Extra Space Storage Inc.'s 2025 annual meeting (May 21, 2025) saw shareholder approval of the Amended and Restated 2015 Incentive Award Plan.
2.  Shareholder voting results on Proposal 3 (advisory approval of named executive officer compensation) showed 172,470,577 votes for and 10,587,202 votes against.

3. The election of 10 board members for terms expiring in 2026 was approved; however, significant "against" votes were cast for several individual directors, ranging from 1,976,757 to 6,940,759 votes.

1. At the Northrop Grumman Corporation's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 21, 2025, shareholders did not approve a shareholder proposal to improve the clawback policy regarding unearned executive pay, receiving only 7,735,052 votes in favor versus 105,755,244 against.
2.  All three management proposals presented at the 2025 Annual Meeting were approved by shareholders.

3. The election of twelve directors at the meeting saw varying levels of support, with the lowest percentage of "For" votes being 88.37% for James S. Turley and the highest being 98.36% for Kimberly A. Ross (May 21, 2025).
1. On May 21, 2025, Travelers Companies, Inc. shareholders approved a 2,100,000-share increase to the company's 2023 Stock Incentive Plan.

2.  In the May 21, 2025 shareholder vote,  the shareholder proposal relating to a report on climate-related pricing and coverage decisions received only 22,459,146 votes in favor, compared to 156,405,642 votes against.
3. Russell G. Golden was appointed Chair of the Audit Committee, replacing Mr. Kane who retired from the Board on May 21, 2025.
Failed to analyze filing
1.  A significant portion of Mohawk Industries Inc. shareholders (between 3 and 7.5 million shares) voted against the re-election of several directors at the May 22, 2025 annual meeting.
2. Shareholders also rejected, via non-binding advisory vote, the executive compensation plan.
3. KPMG LLP was reappointed as the company's independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
1. James C. Foster's employment agreement with Charles River Laboratories International, Inc. has been amended to extend his term by one year, until February 12, 2027.

2.  At the May 20, 2025, annual shareholder meeting, a shareholder proposal by PETA to publish a report on non-human primates imported by the company was not approved, with 38,051,509 shares voted against versus 3,457,547 in favor.
3. Four new directors—Steven Barg, Mark Enyedy, Abraham Ceesay, and Paul Graves—were appointed to the board on May 20, 2025, following the departure of four others.

1. Xcel Energy Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 21, 2025, resulted in the election of all 11 directors nominated by the Board, advisory approval of executive compensation, and ratification of Deloitte & Touche LLP as the independent auditor for 2025.
2.  In the director election (Proposal No. 1),  Richard O’Brien received significantly fewer "For" votes (425,689,215) compared to other directors, who each received over 440 million "For" votes.
3. The advisory vote on executive compensation (Proposal No. 2) showed substantial opposition, with 37,180,904 votes against the proposal.

1. At the 2025 Annual Meeting on May 22, 2025, Welltower Inc. shareholders approved an amendment to the Welltower Inc. Amended and Restated 2022 Long-Term Incentive Plan, with 552,784,549 votes for and 22,424,222 votes against.

2.  Shareholder votes for the election of nine directors ranged from 562,675,781 to 576,227,646, with a significant number of abstentions and broker non-votes (approximately 25,586,546 for each director).
3. The amended Long-Term Incentive Plan, effective May 22, 2025,  has an aggregate share limitation of 20,000,000 shares of common stock, subject to future adjustments.
1. As of April 30, 2025, the company held $7,788 million in assets measured at fair value on a recurring basis, allocated across Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3 inputs of the fair value hierarchy.

2.  A new operating lease agreement for the European headquarters in Dublin, Ireland, with total undiscounted lease payments of $468 million and a 20-year term, is expected to commence in the second quarter of fiscal 2026.

3. In May 2025, the Board of Directors authorized a new $1.0 billion share repurchase program for Class A common stock, adding to the existing $509 million remaining authorization under the August 2024 program.
1. As of May 20, 2025, McDonald's Corporation held its 2025 Annual Shareholders’ Meeting, where 11 nominees were elected to the board of directors.

2.  In the 2025 shareholder vote on Proposal 4 (an advisory shareholder proposal requesting a report related to oversight of advertising risks), only 6,129,398 shares voted in favor, while 496,714,551 voted against.

3.  Shareholder proposals regarding executive compensation and diversity, equity, and inclusion received relatively low support (Proposals 6 and 2 received 7,168,538 and 477,245,245 votes for, respectively), indicating potential future challenges in implementing related changes.
Failed to analyze filing
1. Estée Lauder Companies Inc. changed its fiscal year-end from June 30th to December 31st, effective [Unspecified date, to be determined].
2. The company's bylaws were amended on May 22, 2025, to include indemnification for officers and a forum selection clause requiring litigation of challenges to Delaware court judgments in Delaware.

3.  Numerous graphics related to the amended bylaws ("amendedandrestatedbylaws012.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws015.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws016.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws019.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws023.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws024.jpg", "amendedandrestatedbylaws025.jpg") were included in the 8-K filing.

1. At Honeywell International Inc.'s May 20, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, the “Independent Board Chairman” proposal was rejected, receiving only 110,847,503 votes in favor versus 367,963,930 against.
2.  Shareholders approved the appointment of Deloitte & Touche LLP as independent accountants for 2025, with 544,449,524 votes in favor.
3. The Liability Management Reorganization Proposal was approved by shareholders, receiving 475,299,833 votes in favor.
1. Tapestry, Inc. refinanced its unsecured revolving credit facility on May 22, 2025, replacing a facility dated May 11, 2022, with a new $2 billion facility maturing May 22, 2030.

2. The new credit facility allows for an increase of up to $750 million, subject to conditions, and includes sub-facilities for letters of credit (up to $125 million) and swing line loans (up to $50 million).

3.  The new credit facility contains restrictive covenants limiting Tapestry's ability to incur debt, expand into new businesses, and make certain investments and payments, and requires maintaining a maximum debt-to-EBITDAR ratio of 4.0 to 1.0 (or 4.5 to 1.0 following a material acquisition).

1. Baker Hughes Company's 2025 Annual Meeting on May 20, 2025, resulted in the election of all nominated directors, approval of the executive compensation program, and ratification of KPMG LLP as the independent auditor.
2.  Significant numbers of votes were cast against several director elections, with the highest number of "against" votes (60,552,789) cast against Michael R. Dumais.
3. The executive compensation program received 811,713,298 votes "for" and 62,006,455 votes "against", indicating some shareholder dissent.

1. On May 21, 2025, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. granted its CEO, Marc N. Casper, a 5-year, performance-based restricted stock unit award valued at approximately $60 million to retain his leadership and incentivize shareholder returns.

2. During Mr. Casper's tenure as CEO, Thermo Fisher's annual revenue increased from $10 billion to $43 billion, and its total shareholder return exceeded 800%, more than double the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index's return over the same period.

3. The award's vesting is contingent upon Mr. Casper's continued employment as CEO or Executive Chairman until May 21, 2030, and its payout is tied to Thermo Fisher's total shareholder return relative to the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index from May 1, 2025, to December 31, 2029.
1. At the May 21, 2025 Annual Meeting, Pinnacle West Capital Corporation shareholders approved an advisory vote on executive compensation (92,569,250 for, 3,307,398 against).
2.  Shareholders also approved an amendment to increase the number of authorized common shares (102,015,773 for, 3,408,833 against).
3. A shareholder proposal entitled "Support Special Shareholder Meeting Improvement" was rejected by shareholders (2,501,578 for, 93,354,983 against).

1. On May 21, 2025, the Iowa Utilities Commission approved a $12.7 million annualized revenue increase for Iowa American Water, a subsidiary of American Water Works Company, Inc., driven by over $157 million in capital investments.
2.  Iowa American Water's authorized rate base increased from $144.7 million (approved October 27, 2021) to $262.1 million.
3. The effective date for the new rates will be set by the IUC after Iowa American Water files new rates reflecting the order and the IUC completes its review.
